list_elements.text: Identify suitable language for use in emails at university

While you are at university, you should behave as you would in a professional work
environment – this will prepare you for your career

Most academic staff in the UK will be on first name terms with students – but check this
first
Emails have been an important part of our communication for a number of years now

They don’t need to be as formal as a letter, but not as informal as a text message for
example

It’s better to be too formal than too informal (consider that your email may be forwarded
to another member of staff who you are not so familiar with)
Avoid using shorthand in emails, such as ‘thx’

Use correct grammar, complete sentences and capital letters in the appropriate places (‘I’
not ‘i’)
Make sure your email address is appropriate and professional

Always check you've got the right name in the 'To' box: there are often staff members at
university who have similar names

Make sure your email only goes to the people who need to read it. Remember that if you
reply to all, then everyone will get your email

If you don’t want other recipients to see who else you’ve sent the email to, use the ‘bcc’
field

This sounds obvious, but don't forget to attach attachments! A word of advice – attach the
file you want to send before you start writing. That way, you can't forget to attach it!

DON’T USE CAPITAL LETTERS! If you write in this way, you are basically shouting at
your reader
Short emails can sometimes sound rude, so try to make them polite and friendly

Long emails can be quite off-putting, so consider putting extra information in an
attachment, which the reader can read later

Proofread before you send. If you make mistakes in your email, people will think you also
make mistakes in your work. So always check everything carefully

components.text:
Look at the table for some suggestions on how you might start or finish an email.  The
phrases in red aren't really suitable for addressing academic staff.  You should also avoid the
very formal phrase.

We've got starting and ending phrases, separated into formal and informal.  Your tutor
would probably be happy with 'hi' as a greeting, or 'dear' is also a good one to use.  Avoid the
phrases in red, as they are very informal and not really suitable for addressing a member of
staff.  Remember as well that you may be emailing someone you're familiar with, but that
person might forward it to someone else, so it's probably better to be a little more formal
than you are with your friends.  'Dear Sir or Madam' is probably not necessary though.

well

components.text:
Look in your module handbook and see how much time it is recommended
you spend studying.

You may need more than this if your study background isn't
straightforward, or English isn't your first language.

sections.subtitle: Find out where the time goes

components.text:
Have you ever thought you didn't know where your time went? Many of us have!

Try keeping a log for a week and see exactly how you spend your time. It might be very different from what you think.

See the activity log here: Mindtools website

Do you really need to spend your time in this way? What things could you change to make more room for studying?

However, remember to make time for hobbies, socialising and keeping healthy.

Decide what is important and urgent, and leave tasks which aren't important or urgent until later.

Do you really need to do the things that aren't important?

sections.subtitle: Make a plan, and stick to it

components.text:
Plan exactly when you are going to do what you need to do.

Work backwards from deadlines: what you need to do and how long it will take (e.g. early brainstorming, research methods, searching for information, organising & selecting information, drafts, checking, hand-in).

Put your plan somewhere you can see it or will look at it regularly.

If your plan isn't working - change it! Don't try to stick to something that doesn't work for you.

What distracts you?

How can you stop this?

Try this app: Forest App

list_elements.text: Match tasks to the time you have available
Use blocks of time, e.g. 30 mins

Mix things up: try time blocks of different lengths, and change tasks frequently if
you get bored easily

Plan efficient breaks: longer breaks, micro-breaks, find out what works for you, but
don't work for hours on end without a break
Set early deadlines before hand-in date to allow for last minute alterations
Keep a track of time by using a timer, for example
Make use of available support, e.g. library
Organise your stuff: manage your files and your space, label things clearly
Beware of distractions online: monitor how long you spend
Set times for browsing online as it can easily take up too much time

Allow time for others to respond to you - don't expect tutors or fellow students to
respond straight away - they may be busy too!

components.text:
What strategies do you have for saving time?

Think or share your ideas.

Some things you could try...

list_elements.text: Note-writing: write directly onto laptop if you prefer, using key words
Copying files: keep them somewhere they can be accessed from anywhere
Make the most of spare moments, e.g., listening to a podcast while travelling

Looking for notes: label them clearly with large headings so you can find them
easily

Reading: use techniques for faster reading (see Reading Strategies presentation),
and select and read only what is relevant

Writing references: keep a full record so you don’t have to look them up again (or
use an electronic system)

Thinking: capture ideas as you have them, e.g. in a notebook or make a recording
on your phone

Organising: don’t note same information twice, use highlighting to group
information, keep information in the same place

Avoid duplicating effort: where permitted (e.g. collaborative tasks), share the tasks
so you’re not doing the same things

components.text:
It's easy to put off studying and get distracted. What do you think might motivate you to study and stay on task?

Think about/discuss your ideas, then have a look at the ideas below.

Prospective employers will often ask questions relating to time management in a job
interview.  Some typical questions could be:

list_elements.text: Describe a situation in which you had to work under pressure.
How do you balance your time between your studies and your spare time?

You are sat on reception, answering the telephone when a visitor arrives at the
office and your manager hands you a note to see them straightaway. How do you
respond?

Tell me about a time when you had multiple deadlines to meet; how did you cope
with this situation?

components.text:
(University of Manchester Careers Service, 2016)

In order to answer the questions, you could use one of the following acronyms:

list_elements.text: Context – Say who, when, what, where, how and why this situation was.
Action – Say specifically what you did and how you demonstrated that competence.

Result – Say something specific or quantifiable, a learning point or feedback from
others.
Alternative: STAR (Situation, Task, Action, Result)

components.text:
Targets need to be clear and achievable. We need to know when we have completed them. Vague targets like: “I need to study more” are not useful.

How much is “more”? How will you know you have done more? When will you start?. To make this target useful, we need to identify how much is “more”, e.g. 2 hours per day.

So a more reasonable target might be: “I will study for 2 hours per day starting from today until my exams”.

list_elements.text: Specific
Measurable
Achievable
Realistic
Time-related

components.subtitle: Example
components.text: “I will complete my essay introduction (200 words) by 9p.m. this evening”

list_elements.text: Specific: the introduction
Measurable: I can count the words

Achievable: I’ve already planned the content so I should have the knowledge to complete
the introduction
Realistic: It is not too difficult to write 200 words in one evening
Time-related: by 9p.m.
You need to allow some flexibility in the targets
For example, if you get interrupted and don’t finish a task, extend the ‘deadline’
Monitor targets regularly to see if they are working
If not, change them
Perhaps you were being unrealistic
